[http://www.gnu.org/philosophy/free-software-for-freedom.html "As one person put it, âOpen source is a development methodology; free software is a social movement.â"]
[http://www.gnu.org/philosophy/free-software-for-freedom.html "As one person put it, âOpen source is a development methodology; free software is a social movement.â"]
â   â
The Free Software movement supports individual end user rights by supporting:
  â   â
* organisations that '''may charge''' for any ''support services'' related to that software and
  â
* the ''release of the source and binary code'' to the public, however, '''the author may withhold such releases''' if they choose to do so
  â   â
The Open Source movement supports software developer rights by supporting:
  â   â
* organisations that '''may charge''' for any ''support services'' related to that software and
  â
* the '''release of the source and binary code''' to the public and '''the author is compelled to do so''' at all times.
 
Critics have said that the term âopen sourceâ fosters an ambiguity of a different kind such that it confuses the mere availability of the source with the freedom to use, modify, and redistribute it. Developers have used the [[alternative terms for free software|alternative terms]] ''Free/open source Software'' ([[FOSS]]), or ''Free/Libre/open source Software'' (FLOSS), consequently, to describe open source software which is also free software.
Critics have said that the term âopen sourceâ fosters an ambiguity of a different kind such that it confuses the mere availability of the source with the freedom to use, modify, and redistribute it. Developers have used the [[alternative terms for free software|alternative terms]] ''Free/open source Software'' ([[FOSS]]), or ''Free/Libre/open source Software'' (FLOSS), consequently, to describe open source software which is also free software.
